newsitem.title: LEBANON: Bank of Beirut heads for stock exchange listings.
newsitem.headline: Bank of Beirut heads for stock exchange listings.

text.p: Lebanon's fast-growing Bank of Beirut has announced plans to become the third bank traded on the Beirut Stock Exchange.

The medium-sized bank, which has pioneered consumer loans and savings programmes in post civil war Lebanon, also said it would issue a $50 million three-year Euronote next month that would be listed on the Luxembourg Stock Exchange.

Addressing Beirut financiers on Monday evening, Bank of Beirut Chairman Salim Sfeir said it would this month make a private placement of 20 percent of its shares which would then be listed within a week on the stock exchange and traded three days after that.
The placement would total about $10 million and the proceeds would be re-injected as a cash contribution to capital on behalf of all shareholders, raising the bank's capital to $26-27 million.
Beirut financiers welcomed the announcement. Beirut's re-emerging stock exchange currently lists two banks, the Solidere real estate company and four industrial firms.
The two banks already on the Beirut exchange, Banque Libanaise pour le Commerce and Banque Audi, have been market leaders since listing in December and January respectively.

Bank of Beirut's share placement is being managed by Middle East Capital Group (MECG), a Beirut-based finance house. An MECG source told Reuters the closing date was March 25, but this could be extended.
A bank spokesman said the Euronote issue would be jointly lead managed by a British-based merchant bank and a regional investment bank.
The MECG source said the issue would be made within 40 days of the closure of the capital placement.

Bank of Beirut is the second Beirut bank to announce a Euronote issue this year. Byblos Bank announced a $300 million EuroCD programme last month and said the first $100 million tranche would be issued in the second quarter of the year.

Bank of Beirut Chairman Sfeir told Reuters the bank was also negotiating with the International Finance Corporation (IFC), the private sector arm of the World Bank, to take out a 10-year loan to boost its credit operations for housing and small- and medium-size industry.
The bank was seeking $7-10 million and was one of a group of five Beirut banks negotiating for IFC loans, Sfeir said.

Bank of Beirut ranked 15th among Lebanon's 82 banks in 1996 with total assets of $462.5 million and $16.4 million in shareholders' equity. It has 11 branches in Lebanon and is adding two branches a year and has 164 employees.
